Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: New States of Strongly Interacting Matter in Heavy Ion Collisions
Award.AbstractNarration:
Exploring new states of matter is a fundamental quest. The strong interaction sector of the Standard Model is described by the Quantum Chromodynamics (QCD) as a quantum field theory of quarks and gluons. Such quarks and gluons are deeply confined in normal matter. However when normal matter is heated to a high enough temperature, it changes into a new deconfined form of QCD matter directly made of the quarks and gluons. Such a quark-gluon plasma (QGP) briefly occupied the Universe at about a few microseconds after the "Big Bang", and has now been (re-)created as the hottest matter ever in laboratory by heavy ion collisions ("Little Bang"). Its properties are measured at the Relativistic Heavy Ion Collider (RHIC) as well as the Large Hadron Collider (LHC). Theoretical and experimental studies have suggested that the quark-gluon matter created in heavy ion collisions is strongly-interacting both prior to and after reaching thermal equilibrium. Exactly how such strongly interacting nature arises in the many-body setting from the fundamental QCD theory, is a challenging problem that lacks a deep understanding. This project will investigate this missing link and seek to develop effective descriptions of the matter both in and out of equilibrium. The results will advance our understanding of QCD confinement, provide fresh insights into jet quenching mechanism, make significant progress in search of QCD topological effects, and reduce existing uncertainties on the pre-thermal stage. The expected outcome will contribute to our understanding of fundamental questions such as "how the color confinement phenomenon arises", and "how the experimentally observed properties of the quark-gluon matter in and out of equilibrium emerge from QCD".

The study supported by this award concerns the exploration of new forms of strongly interacting matter under extreme conditions. These activities embody important interdisciplinary aspects, as they are expected to have a profound impact on other areas of physics, ranging from cosmology, supernova, compact stars, to supersymmetric theories, string theories as well as condensed matter physics. This project integrates research with education through mentoring of graduate, as well as undergraduate students. This project will actively pursue a five-year educational outreach plan to develop educational software for computer desktops and mobile devices that utilizes visualization and simulations to demonstrate concepts related to the "Physics of Extreme Matter" in an interactive, engaging, and children-friendly manner.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Nuclear physics studies the subatomic structures and the associated strong interactions that are at the heart of all visible matter. The basic theory, Quantum Chromodynamics (QCD), is however difficult to solve due to its strongly coupled nature. Even its fundamental degrees of freedom, quarks and gluons, are deeply bound inside hadrons under normal circumstances, a phenomenon called "confinement". By colliding heavy ions at high energies, physicists are able to "break up"  hadrons and create a hot "subatomic soup" directly of quarks and gluons --- a new form of matter called a quark-gluon plasma (QGP). The QGP forms at a temperature of one trillion degrees or higher, and briefly occupied the baby Universe. This exotic matter holds the key for understanding our cosmic origin and has now been re-created in laboratories at the Relativistic Heavy Ion Collider (RHIC) and the Large Hadron Collider (LHC), allowing the study of QCD properties in a quark-gluon many-body system. This project has investigated a number of novel emergent phenomena in such an "extreme matter". 

A highly nontrivial aspect of QCD is the emergence of many topological configurations that arise from "twisting" gluon fields across spacetime. In this project, a framework has been developed to describe a many-body ensemble of these topological configurations and to demonstrate that they provide a quantitative understanding of the confinement mechanism. 

The gluon fields are however difficult to detect experimentally. Fortunately the gluon topology can be manifested through quarks when they couple together. The gluon topology can induce a special quantum transport of the quarks, known as Chiral Magnetic Effect (CME). Enthusiastic experimental searches for CME have been carried out at both RHIC and LHC. This project has made significant contributions to the CME-related theory and phenomenology. A new comprehensive tool, a fluid dynamical realization of CME with acronym AVFD, has been developed. The AVFD has demonstrated CME as a quantitative explanation of relevant experimental data and also made testable predictions for upcoming analyses of the isobaric collisions.  

The presence of topological component in QGP can also be probed by the "high speed bullets", or jets, penetrating through the plasma. Their behaviors sensitively depend upon the scatterings they experience with the constituents and thus the energy they lose in the hot medium. Such jet energy loss provides unique "tomography" about what are inside the plasma. An important outcome from this project is the development of a jet energy loss modeling machinery, CUJET3, which provides a successful description of a large body of relevant experimental data at RHIC and LHC. A key finding on the QGP color structure has shown that a chromo-magnetic topological component is indispensable.   

A complete understanding of the heavy ion collision process necessarily requires the study of the earliest moments in such a collision. This is very challenging to describe as the system is far from thermal equilibrium. The research from this project has identified a key feature of this pre-thermal system, namely the gluons in there are highly overpopulated with significantly enhanced scatterings among themselves. This feature leads to a rather rapid evolution toward equilibrium and also transiently produces a novel phenomenon called Bose-Einstein condensation. 

Overall the results from this project have much advanced our understanding of QCD confinement, made significant accomplishments in search of QCD topological effects via CME, provided fresh insights into jet quenching mechanism, and unraveled surprising features of the pre-thermal stage in heavy ion collisions. Such project outcome has contributed substantially to our understanding of fundamental questions such as "how the color confinement phenomenon arises", and "how the experimentally observed properties of the quark-gluon matter in and out of equilibrium emerge from QCD".

The research activities of the project has embodied important interdisciplinary values. Studies on topics like Chiral Magnetic Effect and instantons bear profound impacts on other areas of sciences such as condensed matter physics, cosmology and astrophysics. This project has successfully integrated research with education through mentoring of graduate students as well as providing research experiences for undergraduate students. Based on the present project, two PhD theses have been completed and three undergraduates have been involved in research and become co-authors on six published papers. The project has also actively developed a wide range of public outreach activities. These have included: specifically designed exhibits on "extreme matter" at the annual Indiana University science fest, at the annual Hoosier Association of Science Teachers convention, at many science day or science night events of the local school cooperation; outreach publications in multiple languages, being openly accessible worldwide and wide spread through online science outreach platform and social media; developing various outreach materials like outreach articles and webpages, outreach posters, outreach brochures, popular science tutorial videos, etc. All these outreach efforts have contributed substantially to the dissemination of scientific research results to the widest general audience, generating significantly broader societal impact.
